title: Erdős Problem #503: Maximum Isosceles Sets in Rⁿ
description: What is the maximum size of A ⊆ ℝⁿ with every triple isosceles? f(2)=6 (Kelly), f(3)=8 (Croft). General: C(n+1,2)+1 ≤ f(n) ≤ C(n+2,2) (Blokhuis/Alweiss). OPEN for n ≥ 4.

overview.historicalContext: Erdős Problem #503 asks for the maximum isosceles set size in ℝⁿ. Kelly [ErKe47] solved n=2 (answer 6); Croft [Cr62] solved n=3 (answer 8). Blokhuis [Bl84] proved the upper bound C(n+2,2). Alweiss and Weisenberg gave lower bounds.
overview.problemStatement: What is the largest A ⊆ ℝⁿ such that every three points form an isosceles triangle? Known for n=2,3; open for n ≥ 4. General bounds: C(n+1,2)+1 ≤ f(n) ≤ C(n+2,2).
overview.proofStrategy: We define IsIsoscelesSet via the abstract metric, introduce maxIsoscelesSize as the extremal function, and axiomatize the exact values (n=2,3) and general bounds (Blokhuis upper, Alweiss/Weisenberg lower). Consistency examples use norm_num.
keyInsights: f(2) = 6 (Kelly) and f(3) = 8 (Croft) are the only known exact values
Alweiss lower bound via e_i + e_j vectors: f(n) ≥ C(n+1, 2)
The gap between C(n+1,2)+1 and C(n+2,2) grows linearly in n

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem #503 asks for the maximum isosceles set in ℝⁿ. Exact values are known for n=2 (6) and n=3 (8). The general answer lies between C(n+1,2)+1 and C(n+2,2), but the exact value for n ≥ 4 is open.
conclusion.implications: The gap between the bounds grows linearly in n, suggesting the exact answer may require new geometric ideas beyond coordinate-vector constructions.
openQuestions: What is f(4)? The bounds give 11 ≤ f(4) ≤ 15.
Is the Blokhuis upper bound tight for any n ≥ 4?
Can the Alweiss/Weisenberg lower bound be improved significantly?
